questions.question: What is an antigen?
options: A molecule that can trigger an immune response
A type of white blood cell that attacks pathogens
A protein molecule that neutralizes viral toxins
A chemical signal that induces a systemic fever
questions.explanation: Antigens are usually proteins or polysaccharides on pathogens' surfaces that are recognized as foreign by the immune system, triggering a response.

questions.question: What is an antibody (immunoglobulin)?
options: A Y-shaped protein produced by plasma cells that binds to specific antigens
A specific type of T cell that directly destroys viral-infected host cells
A metabolic enzyme that breaks down the structural walls of most bacteria
A regulatory hormone that maintains the production rate of all immune cells
questions.explanation: Antibodies are proteins secreted by plasma cells (derived from B cells) with binding sites specific to particular antigens.

questions.question: What is the antigen-binding site of an antibody?
options: The variable region at the tips of the Y that recognizes specific antigens
The constant region of the stem that determines the specific antibody class
The chemical stem region that binds to the receptors of various immune cells
The entire Y-shaped structure which acts as a single universal binding receptor
questions.explanation: The variable regions at the ends of the antibody arms have unique shapes that fit specific antigens like a lock and key.

questions.question: How do antibodies help eliminate pathogens?
options: Neutralization, opsonization, agglutination, and complement activation
Directly engulfing and digesting bacteria through cellular phagocytosis
Producing chemical pyrogens that cause fever to inhibit bacterial growth
Converting into specialized T cells that target and kill infected cells
questions.explanation: Antibodies can: neutralize toxins/viruses, coat pathogens for phagocytosis (opsonization), clump cells together (agglutination), and activate complement proteins.

questions.question: What is neutralization by antibodies?
options: Blocking pathogens' ability to infect cells or toxins' harmful effects
Killing pathogens directly with chemicals secreted into the bloodstream
Changing the local pH levels to inhibit the growth of common bacteria
Preventing all immune responses to avoid damage to healthy body tissues
questions.explanation: Antibodies bind to critical sites on viruses or toxins, preventing them from attaching to and entering host cells.

questions.question: What does 'specificity' mean in antibody-antigen interactions?
options: Each antibody recognizes and binds to one specific antigen
Antibodies can bind to any foreign molecule they happen to encounter
Antigens determine which host cells they will infect based on shape
Only certain genetically gifted people can produce effective antibodies
questions.explanation: Due to unique variable regions, each antibody is highly specific to a particular antigenic determinant (epitope), like a specialized key for a specific lock.

questions.question: What is an epitope?
options: The specific part of an antigen that an antibody binds to
The entire complex molecule that makes up a single antigen
The structural constant region found on every antibody molecule
A type of receptor found on the surface of most immune cells
questions.explanation: A single antigen molecule may have multiple different epitopes, each capable of binding a different specific antibody.

questions.question: What are the five classes of antibodies (immunoglobulins)?
options: IgG, IgA, IgM, IgE, IgD
IgA, IgB, IgC, IgD, IgE
Ig1, Ig2, Ig3, Ig4, Ig5
IgM-1, IgM-2, IgM-3, IgM-4, IgM-5
questions.explanation: Different classes have different structures and functions: IgG (most common in blood), IgA (mucosal surfaces), IgM (first responder), IgE (allergies), IgD (B cell receptor).

questions.question: What is opsonization?
options: Antibodies coating pathogens to mark them for phagocytosis
Antibodies directly killing bacteria by rupturing their membranes
Antigens marking healthy body cells as 'self' to avoid attack
The biological process of rapid antibody production in the liver
questions.explanation: 'Opsonin' means 'to prepare for eating' - antibodies act as tags that make pathogens more recognizable and appetizing to phagocytes like macrophages.

questions.question: How does clonal selection explain antibody specificity?
options: Only B cells with receptors for a specific antigen are activated and multiplied
All B cells produce all types of antibodies randomly throughout the body
T cells determine which antibodies B cells will produce for each infection
Antigens select which antibodies they want to bind to based on cell density
questions.explanation: Each B cell has unique receptors. When an antigen binds to matching receptors, that specific B cell is selected to clone itself, producing many identical cells secreting the same specific antibody.
